 QueueTrajectoryGenerator (const TypeInfo *parent)

Detailed Description

Creates a trajectory along queued target points.

This class defines the interface of a generic trajectory generator that creates a smooth trajectory along points specified by the user. Points can be specified in Cartesian coordinates or joint coordinates. All points are stored in a queue and used in first-in first-out (FIFO) order. If there is only one point left in the queue, the trajectory generator plans a deceleration and stop at this point. If there is more than one point in the queue, the trajectory generator uses the current point as a via point and blends the last motion segment with the new motion segment to allow for a smooth transition.

The actual implementation of the trajectory generator is done in a derived class. See the class DefaultTrajectoryGenerator for the default trajectory generator implementation.

Example Program: See the example of the class DefaultTrajectoryGenerator

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

QueueTrajectoryGenerator ( const TypeInfo * parent ) [protected]
 

The constructor performs no action, as this class is only a generic interface. Note that this constructor is protected, i.e., it is only called from the constructor of a derived class.

~QueueTrajectoryGenerator ( ) [virtual]
 

The destructor cleans up.

Member Function Documentation

void setBlockingMovesOn ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the blocking mode such that calls of the "move" function block until the movement is complete (the trajectory generator has reached the queued point).

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setBlockingMovesOff ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the blocking mode such that calls of the "move" function return immediately.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isBlockingMovesOn ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Determines if the blocking mode is enabled for move() commands.

Returns:
true: Blocking mode is enabled
false: Blocking mode is not enabled.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void waitForLastRequestCompleted ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Waits (blocks) until the trajectory generator has reached the last target point (The motion queue is empty after that).

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void waitForRequestCompleted ( MotionId motionId ) [pure virtual]
 

Waits (blocks) until the movement to a certain queued motion point has been completed.

Parameters:
motionId   Specifies the motion point (this value is returned by the move commands).

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

int getNumRequestsInQueue ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Determines the number of motion requests that are queued.

Returns:
Number of queued motion requests.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setJointInterpolationMode ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the joint interpolation mode. In this mode, the trajectory from current position to a target or via point is calculated via interpolating the joint coordinates of these positions. This mode avoids singularities during the motion to the target position and hence, is safer than the Cartesian interpolation mode. The selected interpolation mode is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

This function might fail and set d_status to error if the joint interpolation mode is not implemented.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isJointInterpolationMode ( ) const [pure virtual]
 

Determines if the joint interpolation mode is selected.

Returns:
true: The joint interpolation mode is selected.
false: A different interpolation mode is selected.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setCartesianInterpolationMode ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the Cartesian interpolation mode. In this mode, the trajectory from current position to a target or via point is calculated via interpolating the Cartesian coordinates of these positions. The selected interpolation mode is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

This function might fail and set d_status to error if the Cartesian interpolation mode is not implemented.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

bool isCartesianInterpolationMode ( ) const [pure virtual]
 

Determines if the Cartesian interpolation mode is selected.

Returns:
true: The Cartesian interpolation mode is selected.
false: A different interpolation mode is selected.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setJointVelocityLimit ( const VectorBase<>& velocityLimit ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the maximum velocity for each joint. Note that the final velocity limits are determined by multiplying this value with the speed scale factor. The selected velocity limits are used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

The velocity limits are updated with the default velocity limits of the manipulator whenever the trajectory generator is connected to a manipulator.

Parameters:
velocityLimit   The maximum velocity joint vector. Each element of this vector is in degrees/sec (revolute joint) or meters/sec (prismatic joint).

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void getJointVelocityLimit ( VectorBase<>& velocityLimit ) [pure virtual]
 

Gets the maximum velocity for each joint.

Parameters:
velocityLimit   The current velocity limit joint vector.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setSpeedScale ( double speedScale ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the speed scale to a new value. The speed scale is a factor that is multiplied with the velocity limits before they are used. Hence, setting the speed scale is a handy way to quickly set the trajectory generator to different overall speeds. The selected speed scale is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

Parameters:
speedScale   The new speed scale.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

double getSpeedScale ( ) const [pure virtual]
 

Determines the current speed scale.

Returns:
The current value of the speed scale.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

void setBlendingTime ( double blendingTime ) [pure virtual]
 

Sets the blending time to a new value. The selected blending time is used by all following calls to move(). It does not have any effect on already queued motion requests.

Parameters:
blendingTime   The new blending time.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

double getBlendingTime ( ) [pure virtual]
 

Determines the current blending time.

Returns:
The current blending time.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( const Transform & endEffectorTransform ) [pure virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point, specified by an end-effector transform. Note that this function might fail if there is no inverse kinematics implemented for the specified manipulator, or no manipulator is connected to the trajectory generator.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_status is set to error.

Parameters:
endEffectorTransform   The end-effector transform to queue.
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Examples: 

     DefaultTrajectoryGenerator tragen;
    
     // Move the end-effector to a certain Cartesian position.
     tragen.move(translation(0, 20, 0) * xRotation(30));

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( VectorBase<>& jointEndPosition ) [pure virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point, specified by a vector that contains a joint position for each joint.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_status is set to error.

Parameters:
jointEndPosition   The joint vector of the target/via point to queue, each joint position is in degrees (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId move ( int jointNumber,
double position ) [pure virtual]
 

Queues a new target/via point that has the same joint coordinates as the last queued point except a specfied joint coordinate that has a different value.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_status is set to error.

Parameters:
jointNumber   Joint that has the new position (0 = first joint).
position   The new position, in degrees (revolute joint)/meters (prismatic joint).
Returns:
A reference to the motion point.

Examples: 

     DefaultTrajectoryGenerator tragen;
    
     // Move the first joint to 90 degrees.
     tragen.move(0, 90);

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.

MotionId stop ( double stopTime ) [pure virtual]
 

Queues a stop request. This stop request, when taken out of the queue, causes a deceleration in the trajectory, until a complete stop (constant setpoint) for a certain time.

If blocking is enabled (setBlockingMovesOn()), the function blocks until the move is completed, otherwise the move is queued and the function returns immediately. If the motion queue is full, d_status is set to error.

Parameters:
stopTime   Stop time, includes deceleration time.

Reimplemented in DefaultTrajectoryGenerator.
